translated: Sutra of the Wise and Foolish, Scroll 10
Translated by the Yao Qin Dynasty monk Zhu Fonian from Liangzhou
Chapter 8: On Learning, Chapter on Learning
Guarding against evil conduct of the body, rectifying one's own bodily conduct, guarding against evil of the body,
cultivating good conduct of the body.
As for guarding against evil conduct of the body, why is it called evil conduct of the body?

Because one knows one's own inner faults and the faults of others, it is called evil conduct. After evil is fully manifested, one's complexion changes, or one uses one's fists to harm and destroy one's body. These evil matters do not bring peace and security in this world or the next, and one may fall into the realms of hungry ghosts or animals with an ugly appearance;
if born among humans, one's abilities are inferior to others.

There was a brahman who was bitten by a dog. The brahman became angry and his body and mind were filled with rage. He insisted on punishing the evil dog to prevent it from being violent and tyrannical.
His parents said to him:ğŸ”½Brahman!
Can a brahman bite a dog just as a dog bites a brahman?
The brÄhmaá¹‡a replied to his parents:
I must discipline the dog to prevent it from being unrestrained and poisonous.
His parents told their son:
If you do not follow my instructions, do as you please.
At that time, the brÄhmaá¹‡a caught the dog, bound it, and beat it with a stick.
When he beat it, there were two unrighteousnesses:
The grass rope injured the dog's feet and also caused it to lose its feces.
This kind of sentient being is also like this, arguing over small matters and causing great harm to the body.

The buddhas, the world-honored ones, with great compassion, teach sentient beings not to argue, but sentient beings do not follow their teachings. Entangled by anger, they give rise to two unrighteousnesses, are bound by various sufferings, and will again experience the afflictions of hell, hungry ghosts, and animals. Although they may become human, their appearance is ugly. Such afflictions are innumerable and cannot be fully recorded. Therefore, the World-Honored One speaks of guarding against evil conduct of the body.
Having guarded against evil conduct of the body, what merits are obtained?
Answer:
Obtaining two merits and a good reputation.
What are the two?

If one is in the heavenly palace receiving blessings naturally, the halls of the seven treasures are suspended in the void. If one is born among humans, one's appearance is upright, and those who see it rejoice and all come to pay homage. In the great assembly, one is revered by millions of people, like the moon alone illuminating the many stars that revolve around it.
Therefore it is said, Guarding against evil conduct of the body.
What merits does one who rectifies one's own body obtain?
What is the reputation?
The answer is:
In this present life, one also obtains a good reputation. If one's body perishes and life ends, one will also obtain a good reputation.
How does one obtain a good reputation in this present body?
If in this present body one's comings and goings are seen and worshipped by millions of people;
If the body perishes and life ends, one will be born in a good place, in the heavens.
What other merits are there in rectifying one's own body?
The answer is:
Evil demons and violent ghosts cannot take advantage of them, and enemies cannot catch them.
Then, he spoke in verse:
Enemies fill the world, wanting to catch them,
Evil befalls them, like a snake biting itself.
The body is the root of suffering and the mind is the source of calamity. Therefore, the World-Honored One said, Correct one's own bodily actions.
Why is it said to guard against evil in the body?
Evil conduct leads to falsehood, as it is said.
Evil wealth, evil children, evil clothes, evil places, and evil lands are all called evil.
Sometimes evil is done by known relatives, sometimes evil is done by unknown relatives. Therefore, the TathÄgata speaks of guarding against evil in the body.
As for cultivating goodness in the body, there are two kinds of good conduct, as it is said.

Good wealth, good children, good clothing, good dwelling, good land, cultivating good conduct with the body, and being respectful to the Buddha, the Saá¹…gha, parents, and elders without transgression, for this reason the World-Honored One speaks of cultivating good conduct with the body.ğŸ”½Guarding against evil conduct of speech,
Correcting one's own speech, guarding against evil speech,
Cultivating good conduct of speech.
Why is it said to guard against evil conduct of speech?

Knowing one's own internal faults and knowing the faults of others is called evil conduct. If one has already given rise to anger and speaks slanderously, falsely creating faults, causing countless multitudes to give rise to evil thoughts, yet not being self-aware and also not knowing, later receiving evil retribution and all harboring anger, that slanderer will later enter hell, hungry ghosts, and animals and experience immeasurable suffering.
If reborn among humans, they will be much slandered and their words will not be trusted.
Those who can guard their speech will naturally attain blessings and rewards, and be reborn in the heavens with natural bliss. If reborn as a human, they will not be subjected to harsh words.
Therefore it is said, Guard against evil speech.
What merits does one attain by rectifying one's own speech?
The answer is:

One will be praised and spoken of by countless people, saying, 'This person is virtuous and upright, and their actions accord with their words. Their speech is not coarse, they do not seek others' shortcomings or criticize others' faults, and their words are dignified and not forceful.'
Therefore it is said, Rectify one's own speech.
Guard against evil speech has two meanings:
Either one should be silent like the sages, or one should speak the Dharma and its meaning.

Before wanting to speak, one should first regulate oneself. Words that lead to one's own downfall do not affect only oneself. If one utters coarse words, people will dislike them, and no one will respect or serve them when they come and go.
Therefore it is said, Guard against evil speech.

Cultivating good conduct of speech means that those who cultivate good conduct have a compassionate mind, speak softly without hurting others' feelings, and are loved by many people. Therefore, it is said to cultivate good conduct of speech.
Guarding against evil conduct of mind, rectifying one's own mental conduct, guarding against evil of mind,
cultivating good conduct of mind.
As for guarding against evil conduct of mind, among the three types of mental conduct, it is the foremost. In an instant of thought, it can turn cities, towns, and villages into ruins.
As it is said in the sutra:
Householder, have you heard of the empty wilderness of flowing sand, the empty wilderness of following ascetics, and the empty wilderness of seclusion?
The elder said to the Buddha:
I have heard of the empty wilderness of flowing sand, the empty wilderness of following ascetics, and the empty wilderness of seclusion.
The Buddha told the householder:
Householder, how is it?
Who created this empty wilderness of flowing sand and the empty wilderness of following ascetics?
The elder said to the Buddha:
All this is due to the evil thoughts of the immortals. The spells they cast created this empty wilderness of shifting sands, following the empty wilderness of the monks.
As the Sutra of Practice says:
Nineteen people upheld the correct practice, but only one should not be in a secluded place, because their verbal karma is evil. Practitioners do not allow this person to stay in the wilderness.
He told that person:

Your mind harbors evil, and your thoughts are not good. You should stay in the human realm, recite scriptures, and assist in various matters. Disturbing the mind can lead to attaining the fruit of the Way.
If you try to seek an empty mind in emptiness, your mind will be constantly disturbed and always give rise to evil, leading to self-destruction and not reaching the good path.
Those who do not guard their minds will follow their thoughts and enter the realms of hell, hungry ghosts, and animals.
Even if one attains birth as a human, one will fall into a lowly class, be disliked by others, and not be happy when seen.

Those who can protect the mind, if born in the heavens, will naturally receive golden beds, jade tables, and palaces of the seven treasures. If born as a human, they will be loved and respected by others.
Therefore, it is said to protect against evil actions of the mind.

As for the practice of rectifying one's own mind, the mind is difficult to restrain and control when it runs wild with thoughts. Due to the arising of thoughts in the mind, one is able to accomplish things. The body's perilous and wonderful practices retreat and turn away from the almost accomplished realization, becoming an ordinary person again. Therefore, it is said to practice rectifying one's own mind.

As for protecting against evil of the mind, calming the mind and not giving rise to thoughts and attachments, cultivating the practice of rectifying the mind and collecting the mind in single-pointed focus, therefore it is said to protect against evil of the mind.

As for the practice of cultivating good of the mind, the mind thinks of good practices, the body cultivates the correct Dharma, and the mouth proclaims the teachings. The two matters depend on the mind up to the state of no-more-training. Therefore, it is said to be the practice of cultivating good of the mind.
And evil conduct of speech and mind,
And all defilements and evils.
As for abandoning evil conduct of body, one abandons evil conduct of body, forever extinguishing it without remainder. Therefore it is said, Abandoning evil conduct of body.
As for evil conduct of speech, what is spoken should not express evil dharmas, and one should not spread out evil matters. Therefore it is said, And evil conduct of speech.

As for abandoning evil conduct of mind, the mind should not think of various unwholesome dharmas, and one should not give rise to a harmful mind towards sentient beings. Therefore it is said, Abandoning evil conduct of mind.

As for all defilements and evils, various external unwholesome dharmas that accompany the mind, which do not benefit oneself and also do not benefit others, one should seek to extinguish them and not allow them to arise. Therefore it is said, And all defilements and evils.ğŸ”½Cultivating good conduct of body,
And good conduct of speech, and cultivating good conduct of mind,
Without desire, exhausting the contaminants.
As for practicing good conduct with the body, one does not engage in evil conduct with the body.
There are three types of bodily conduct:

Not killing, not stealing, and not engaging in sexual misconduct. Cultivating these three karmas and rectifying one's bodily conduct, making offerings to the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹…gha, sweeping and repairing dilapidated stupas and temples, this is why it is said to be practicing good conduct with the body.

As for the mouth also being good, the mouth has four faults. Not speaking falsely, not speaking harshly, not causing disputes between others, and not engaging in frivolous speech. Praising and speaking of the Buddha's merits, praising the Dharma and the Saá¹…gha of bhiká¹£us, serving one's parents, teachers, friends, and elders, this is why it is said that the mouth is also good.

As for practicing good conduct with the mind, the mind has three faults. Not giving rise to jealousy, anger, delusion, or wrong views, but only giving rise to various good merits, not following inverted views and falling into the realm of heterodox paths, this is why it is said to be practicing good conduct with the mind.
One without desire and who has exhausted defilements means a person without desire has immeasurable, vast, and limitless functions.
One who has exhausted defilements means the various obscurations and afflictions do not arise again.
Therefore it is said, one without desire and who has exhausted defilements.
Cultivating good conduct with the body, speech, and mind, in future lives,
one will be forever reborn in a good place.
As for cultivating good conduct with the body, it is asked:
Why is it insufficient to cultivate good conduct with the body above, and why is it necessary to explain it again?
The reply is:

The TathÄgata's teachings are received by various disciples. Some wish to hear the meaning in detail, while some wish to hear the essential points concisely. For those who wish to hear the essential points concisely, the five aggregates of suffering are roughly mentioned. For those who wish to hear the meaning in detail, the conduct of body, speech, and mind are individually explained in order, with the corresponding evidence and understanding.
There are also those who wish to hear the detailed explanation and the concise explanation. Therefore, the TathÄgata extensively explains this verse.
As it is said, one who practices good conduct with the body, this is called the extensive explanation. The same applies to speech and mind. This is called the concise explanation.

The TathÄgata observes the minds of the assembly in front and expounds the meaning to enable them to receive the teachings, and also causes the people who receive the teachings to have their wishes fulfilled.
All good conduct benefits sentient beings and accomplishes much. Therefore, it is said, Practice good conduct with the body, speech, and mind.
In this world and in the next world, one experiences bliss and inexhaustible blessings for a long time, and is forever reborn in a good realm.
There are two kinds of receiving blessings:
worldly blessings and uncontaminated blessings.
Therefore, it is said, Forever reborn in a good realm.
Compassionate and benevolent, not killing, always able to restrain the body, this is the place of immortality,
wherever one goes, there are no worries.
Compassionate and benevolent, not killing, never harming or disturbing living beings, not robbing others of their wealth, not engaging in sexual misconduct with others' spouses.
What is meant by benevolent? One attains to tread the path of the wise and virtuous Dharma, therefore it is said, Benevolence is not killing.

Always able to restrain the body means to be cautious day and night, to control one's actions like guarding a precious vase, rather to lose one's body and life by accepting punishment and execution, than to rely on one's body and life to create unwholesome actions.

In the past, there was a Chandalas family that gave birth to seven sons. Six older brothers attained the path of Srota-apannas, while the youngest was still an ordinary person. The mother, a Chandalas woman, attained the path of Anagamins. The seven brothers all accepted the five precepts and became the Buddha's disciples.

According to the ancient customs of that country, the law of the Chandalas required them to carry out executions. If there were any serious crimes such as murder, theft, or adultery in the country, they would all be executed by the Chandalas.
At that time, the ruler of the country summoned the eldest son,
Now there are those who deserve to die. You go and execute them.
The man then bowed to the king and pleaded with him, saying:ğŸ”½I have already attained the path of Srota-apannas. How can I commit the crime of taking life?

I wish the great king would be magnanimous, receive the five precepts himself, become a disciple of the Buddha, dare not kill, guard the body with utmost care, not think of evil, and rather kill oneself than violate the precepts and harm even an ant.
At that time, the king, with the majestic heavenly authority of his wrath greatly swelling, said to the man:
You are the people of the country and I am the lord of the country. If you do not follow my teachings, you will instead believe in the Buddha's empty words.
He then ordered a minister beside him to quickly take the man to the market to be executed.
The man again said to the king:
My body is the people of the king and my heart is my own. Do as you wish, kill me if you will.
He was then taken to the market and beheaded. The king asked a minister beside him:
Who else remains of the man who was supposed to be executed just now?
The minister replied to the king:
There are six other strong brothers left.
The king ordered those beside him to summon them one by one and again ordered the executioner to kill them.
The man said in reply:ğŸ”½If you kill me, I will not be able to see my brothers again.
I have taken the five precepts from the Buddha and dare not kill.
The king became even more furious and had him killed.
In this way, he summoned all six brothers, and they all said they had taken the precepts and did not dare to kill. The king became even more enraged and had them all killed.
Next, he summoned the youngest brother and his mother to come together. When the king saw the mother come, he became even more furious.
You did not send the mother of the six sons who were previously killed. Why did you come when you were summoned for the youngest son?
The mother said to the king:
Please listen to my humble words and I will explain the reason.

The previous six sons have all attained the path of stream-entry. Even if the king were to seize those six people and crush their bodies into dust, they would not give rise to evil thoughts as small as a hair.

Now, this youngest one is still an ordinary person. Although his body practices goodness, he has not yet received the nourishing of the Dharma. Therefore, I think of my son who has not yet attained the Way, and worry that he may lose his mind and, out of fear of the king's orders, out of concern for his own life, break the precepts and commit killing. That is why I sent him here.

He will break the precepts and follow the king's orders, unfilial and committing killing. When his body perishes and his life ends, he will enter the Tai Shan Hell. Out of pity for my son, I sent him here.
The king asked the mother again:
Did the six sons who died before all attain the path of stream-entry?
She replied:
They all attained it.
The king asked the mother again:
What path has the mother herself attained?
The mother replied:
I have attained the path of non-returner.

When the king heard these words, he threw himself to the ground. The ministers helped him up and sprinkled water on him. After a long while, he regained consciousness and lamented and reproached himself:
I have created immeasurable roots of offenses. Letting my mind run wild, I killed six stream-enterers.

The afflictions of body and mind made it impossible to sit still. He immediately prepared fragrant oil and firewood, obtained six corpses, cremated them, and built six stupas to make offerings and pay respects, repenting three times a day, wishing for his offenses to be gradually extinguished and become thin.
He also took out his wealth to give to the old mother, and on fast days he repented frequently, hoping to reduce his offenses and avoid hell.
Therefore it is said, Always able to control the body.

SrotÄpannas, saká¹›dÄgÄmins, anÄgÄmins, and arhats guard the precepts without deficiency. Although ordinary people guard the precepts, their minds are like a whirlwind and cannot be constantly still. Therefore it is said, Always able to control the body.

Those who attain the fruits, when they abandon the male body, will still obtain a male body; when they abandon the noble body, they will still obtain a noble body. They will never harbor worries or fears of hell, hungry ghosts, or animals. The body of an anÄgÄmin will not return to the world from that heaven. An arhat is forever free from sorrow and distress, with all afflictions exhausted, entering the realm of the unconditioned, tranquil and extinguished.
Therefore it is said, This is where there is no death.

Where one goes is free from trouble means in that realm of the unconditioned, there are ultimately no afflictions, no worries or sorrows, no suffering or distress, and no death or longing. Therefore it is said, Where one goes is free from trouble.
Non-killing is benevolence, always able to be cautious with speech, this is where there is no death,
where one goes is free from trouble.
Non-killing is benevolence means one will never believe slanderous people who give rise to harmful thoughts in the midst of this. Therefore it is said, Non-killing is benevolence.
Those who always carefully watch their speech, even if scolded, cursed, or spoken to with coarse words, consider it all empty and silent, without form, just like the sages who are never angry.
If there is something done, it is all provisional transformation, not truly angry. Or if one thinks it in the mind but does not speak it, even if spoken, one soon feels ashamed.
Therefore it is said, Always carefully watch your speech, this is where one does not die, and wherever one goes there will be no trouble.
Non-killing is benevolence, always carefully watch the mind, this is where one does not die,
wherever one goes there will be no trouble.

Those who attain this, even if they encounter a hundred thousand sufferings, their body falls into the waves and deep abyss, or falls into a fiery pit of raging flames, they will never be afraid to the point of changing their mind. Day and night they regulate their mind to prevent it from going astray, just like when one defeats an enemy and kills them, adding poison afterwards. Those who attain this eliminate afflictions in the mind like an enemy that is not completely destroyed.
They think again and again:

The practitioner observes the success and failure of the five aggregates, and moves from the defiled mind to the undefiled realm, realizing impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and no-self. Having attained the undefiled state, he guards and does not lose it.
Why is it so?
The practitioner always thinks to himself:

'From beginningless time, I have been attached to birth and death, and transmigrated in the world of swords and violence. I have always cultivated this mind, creating offenses without end, and have been controlled by the mind like a person controlling a slave.
I have now subdued and tamed my mind, and will now guard it again to prevent it from going astray.'
Therefore it is said, Not killing is benevolence, always able to be cautious of the mind. This is where there is no death, and wherever one goes there is no trouble.
Being cautious of the body is courageous, being cautious of the mouth is also courageous,
Being cautious of the mind is courageous, and so are all bonds.
This place is called immortality, wherever one goes there is no worry or trouble.

As for being courageous and bold, one who is knowledgeable about the past and present, has high talent and clear virtue, and is proficient in skills and wisdom, abandons evil dharmas, and practices what the body cultivates without indulging in desire, is therefore said to be courageous and bold in guarding the body.

As for being courageous and bold in guarding the mouth being the same, what comes out of the mouth is first a smile and then words that do not hurt others' feelings, therefore it is said to be courageous and bold in guarding the mouth being the same.

As for being courageous and bold in guarding the mind, the mind has already become gentle and disciplined, and does not give rise to evil thoughts, therefore it is said to be courageous and bold in guarding the mind.
As for all bonds being the same, it is asked:
The three matters of body, speech, and mind have already been accomplished, what is lacking that it is said all bonds are the same?
The answer is:
As it is said, one should come and go, advance and stop, sew and mend, and should do what should be done, but does not do it, this is all lacking in what the body should practice and not practicing.
The practitioner is able to be fully equipped with these practices.
Therefore it is said, Be cautious in body, this is the heroic practice.

As for the remaining actions of speech, one should follow the teachings and precepts of the sages, and not engage in male or female sounds, not engaging in any such sounds, this is called the remaining actions of speech.
What is meant by the remaining actions of mind creating further conditions for rebirth?

This is the remaining action of the mind. A practitioner can see these various actions, fully perfecting the remaining actions of body, speech, and mind. Therefore it is said, All bonds are also like this.

This place is called the immortal, the extinction of nirvana, without end or beginning, without coming or going, without birth or cessation, attachment or cutting off. Therefore it is said, this place is called the immortal.

The reason for saying free from worries and afflictions is that due to clothes, food and drink, bedding, medical supplies, servants, elephants, horses, carriages, national wealth, wives and children, all give rise to worries and afflictions. Without these, there are no worries. Therefore, it is said to be free from worries and afflictions.
It is good to protect the body, and it is also good to protect the mouth,
It is good to protect the mind, and it is also good to protect everything,
If a bhiká¹£u protects everything, he can end the root of suffering.

As for it is good to protect the body, if one can single-mindedly guard the body, the heavenly beings and worldly people will praise its virtue. The eight groups of heavenly dragons, spirits, and ghosts will all praise its virtue, and day and night they will assist and encourage its completion. Therefore, it is said to be good to protect the body.

The same is true for guarding speech well. If one cultivates unwholesome karma, or is scolded and reviled by others, one should maintain a firm mind and guard one's speech, never retaliating. The gods and people of the world will all praise it as good. Therefore, it is said that the same is true for guarding speech well.

Guarding the mind is excellent. If someone beats or cuts one's body, or scolds and reviles one, the practitioner should maintain a pure mind and not give rise to anger. The gods and people of the world will all praise it as good. Therefore, it is said that guarding the mind is excellent.

The same is true for guarding everything. In addition to guarding the body and speech, one should also be careful and protect the other practices. Therefore, it is said that the same is true for guarding everything.

The bhiká¹£u guards everything. The practicing bhiká¹£u guards the body, mind, and other external practices, fully equipped with dignified deportment and etiquette. Therefore, it is said that the bhiká¹£u guards everything.
Able to end the suffering of the cycle of birth and death. Since one is equipped with this practice, how could one go to the evil paths?

Completely cutting off the paths of hell, animals, and hungry ghosts, and being able to completely cut off human suffering and human pain, therefore it is said that one can reach the end of the source of suffering.
Guarding speech and mind is pure, and the body never does evil,
Being able to purify these three, one then attains the path of the immortals.
As for guarding speech and mind is pure, among the three kinds of ruin, there is ruin of life, ruin of the kalpa, and ruin of bonds, these are called the three kinds of ruin.

When ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha appeared in the world, he was in a defiled world with a human lifespan of one hundred years. His disciples did not guard against faults of speech and often violated the precepts. Even while the sage was in the world, he still violated the precepts, let alone in the last one thousand years when he was able to preserve the precepts and rules?
The Buddha's sutras say:
In the last one thousand years, when the true Dharma is about to perish, there will be seven defiled practices that will spread in the world.
What are the seven?
If someone upholds the precepts for one hundred years, they will be destroyed by bad friends in the time it takes to snap one's fingers.
Second, even if one has long practiced loving-kindness, one can be destroyed by anger in an instant.
Third, one disdains proper conduct and does not follow the teachings.
Fourth, one argues over right and wrong and disputes over victory and defeat.
Fifth, in cities, villages, and towns, one spreads rumors from east to west.
Sixth, one becomes greedy for offerings and thus contracts infectious diseases.
Seventh, from ordinary people to arhats, all are insulted and attain nirvana.
The reason for slander is all due to not guarding one's speech.
The Venerable SÄgata, an arhat, said:
Always teaching and transforming hungry ghosts.

He went to the realm of hungry ghosts and saw a hungry ghost with an ugly appearance, so hideous that those who saw it would stand on end in fear. His body emitted blazing flames like a great bonfire, his mouth produced maggots, pus and blood flowed out, and the foul stench permeated far and wide, making it unbearable to approach.

Some vomited flames from their mouths, tens of fathoms long, some emitted flames from their ears, noses, eyes, bodies, and limbs, tens of fathoms long. Their lips hung down like wild boars, their bodies were a yojana long, they scratched themselves with their hands, and ran around crying out.
At that time, the Venerable PÅ«rá¹‡a asked the hungry ghosts:
What offenses did you commit in your past lives, that you now suffer this pain?
The hungry ghosts replied:

When we were in the world in the past, we went forth and became monks, but we were attached to our dwellings, stingy and unwilling to part with them. We maintained our deportment but spoke foul words.

If we saw monks who upheld the precepts and practiced diligently, we would scold and insult them, sometimes mocking them, sometimes glancing at them askance, sometimes doing what was right as wrong, and sometimes doing what was wrong as right.

Relying on their noble lineage, they consider themselves immortal, creating immeasurable roots of unwholesomeness. It would be better to cut off their tongues with a sharp knife and endure the suffering from the wounds, rather than slandering diligent bhiká¹£us for a single day.

If you return to JambudvÄ«pa, you can warn the bhiká¹£us on my behalf, to be careful with their words and not speak falsely. If they see bhiká¹£us who practice pure conduct and uphold the precepts, they should proclaim their virtues.

Since I received this hungry ghost body, I have experienced such suffering for hundreds of years, thousands of years, tens of thousands of years, and millions of years. After my life ends, I will enter hell.

At that time, the hungry ghost, having said this, raised his voice and wailed, throwing himself to the ground, like Mount Tai collapsing, the heavens overturning, and the earth being turned upside down.
This is caused by the fault of the mouth. Those who can guard against the fault of the mouth will receive blessings without end.
KÄÅ›yapa TathÄgata appeared in the world, expounded the Dharma, taught and transformed as much as possible, and entered parinirvÄá¹‡a in the realm of nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder.
After his nirvÄá¹‡a, there was a Tripiá¹­aka monk named PÄ«tadruma. The Saá¹…gha ordered him:
You are not to be assigned any miscellaneous tasks. Simply expound the wonderful Dharma to the later students.

At that time, the Tripiá¹­aka monk inwardly despised [the Saá¹…gha's order] and did not dare disobey it. He then expounded the meaning of the sÅ«tras to the later students. He called out to the one who received the meaning, saying:
Quickly come forward, you with an elephant's head.

Next, he called out to the second one, saying, You with a horse's head. Next, You with a camel's head. Next, You with an ass's head. Next, You with a pig's head. Next, You with a sheep's head. Next, You with a ram's head. Next, You with a lion's head. Next, You with a tiger's head. Next, You with a bird's head. Next, You with a bear's head. In this way, he called out to countless kinds of beasts.

The Tripiá¹­aka master Huangyan spoke such innumerable evil words from his mouth. Although he bestowed the meaning of the sÅ«tras, he did not escape his crimes. When his body perished and his life ended, he entered hell, experiencing suffering for countless thousands of myriads of kalpas.

The remaining crimes were not yet completed, so after leaving hell, he was born in the great ocean and received a water-based form. His body had a hundred heads and was extremely large. When other creatures saw him, they all ran away.

At that time, the World-Honored One saw that many bhiká¹£us mutually slandered each other, not being careful with their verbal faults. They either spoke coarsely, leading to anger, or what they said seemed like a joke, arousing old grudges. They either used their wisdom to look down on others, and those others did not believe or submit, or they spoke of the lowly origins of others, using it to create resentment.

At that time, the World-Honored One knew that the bhiká¹£us had many differences and feared they would later fall into crimes. He then used his spiritual powers to bring the bhiká¹£us to the great ocean to see the animal that received the punishment of having a body with a hundred heads, wanting to make the bhiká¹£us change their past and cultivate the future.
He asked the sinful insect:
Are you the one called Huang Yan?
The insect replied:
